Question:
Why was this treatise composed?
Answer:
In order to stop the view of a person and to reveal the rarity of wisdom.
Stopping the view of a person means that these form and formless dharmas are ultimately without a person.
Revealing the rarity of wisdom means that for the wise and intelligent, using these two dharmas they understand all dharmas.
Why is this?
Because these two dharmas can encompass all dharmas.
For this reason, this treatise was composed.
What are form dharmas?
Answer:
Ten sense bases and a small part of one sense base.
The ten sense bases are eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, form, sound, smell, taste, and touch.
The small part of one sense base refers to the dharma sense base.
What are formless dharmas?
Answer:
One sense base refers to the mind sense base, and one part of one sense base refers to the dharma sense base.
Question:
What are the dharmas that are form?
What are the dharmas that are not form?
Answer:
If a dharma is called form and its substance is form, it is form;
If a dharma is not called form and its substance is not form, it is not form.
Furthermore, if a dharma is the four great elements and what is derived from the four great elements, it is form;
If a dharma is not the four great elements and not what is derived from the four great elements, it is not form.
Furthermore, if the four great elements are the cause and its substance is derivative form, it is form;
If a dharma does not take the four great elements as its cause and its substance is not derivative form, it is not form.
Furthermore, if a dharma can be born, grow, and increase, it is form;
If it is contrary to this, it is not form.
Venerable Vasumitra said:
What is the characteristic of form in this context?
Answer:

The meaning of gradual coming is the characteristic of form, the meaning of gradual destruction is the characteristic of form, the meaning of having a location is the characteristic of form, the meaning of obstruction is the characteristic of form, the meaning of always having decrease when together with an enemy is the characteristic of form.
Furthermore, there are three meanings that are the characteristic of form:
There is form that is visible and has resistance, there is form that is invisible but has resistance, and there is form that is invisible and has no resistance.
The meaning of having a characteristic that can be accepted or rejected is the characteristic of form, and furthermore, the meaning of obstruction is the characteristic of form.
Question:
Past and future form, as well as unconditioned form, should not be form.
Answer:
They are also form because they have the characteristic of form.
Past form is that which has already obstructed, future form is that which will obstruct, although a single atom cannot obstruct, a collection can obstruct.
Although unconditioned form is unobstructing, its basis is obstructing.
What is the basis?
It refers to the four great elements.
Because the four great elements are obstructive, they are also obstructive.
It is like a tree moving and its shadow also moving.
Moreover, the characteristic of form is the meaning of being able to be removed.
Moreover, the characteristic of form is the meaning of having one characteristic.
The characteristics of form in the eye and form sense base are different, up to the characteristics of form in the dharma sense base are different.
Venerable Buddharaká¹£ita said:
The characteristic of form is the meaning of obstruction and destruction, and the opposite of this is the characteristic of formlessness.
Question:
Why is form in the dharma sense base not mentioned in the ten sense bases?
Answer:
If form passes through a moment and has the nature of a particle, it is in the ten sense bases;
although form in the dharma sense base passes through a moment, it does not have the nature of a particle, therefore it is not mentioned.
Moreover, if form is the basis of the five consciousnesses and the object of the five consciousnesses, it is mentioned in the ten sense bases;
form in the dharma sense base is neither the basis of the five consciousnesses nor the object of the five consciousnesses, therefore it is not mentioned.
Question:
Are the forms of the form realm more numerous or are the forms of the desire realm more numerous?
Answer:
If by means of the sense bases, the forms of the desire realm are more numerous.
Why is this?
The forms of the desire realm are two sense bases and nine sense bases in part, while the forms of the form realm are nine sense bases in part.
If by means of the substance, the forms of the form realm are more numerous.
Why is this?

There are two dharmas:
Visible dharmas and invisible dharmas.
Question:
Why was this treatise composed?
Answer:
In order to stop the views of people and to show the rarity of wisdom, as explained above in detail.
Moreover, some say that this treatise was composed in order to stop the intention of those who hold the combined meaning.
Some say that all dharmas are visible.ğŸ”½As the Venerable Ghoá¹£a and others say:
Ghoá¹£a said:
All dharmas are visible, because they are the objects of the wisdom eye.
In order to stop those who speak like this, and also to clarify that dharmas are visible and invisible, this treatise is composed.
What are visible dharmas?
The answer is:
One sense base, namely the form sense base.
What are invisible dharmas?
The answer is:
Eleven sense bases.
The question is asked:
Why is it said that one among the ten form sense bases is visible, while the others are not visible?
The answer is:
Because the form sense base is coarse and directly perceptible, as explained in detail in the chapter on the twelve sense bases.
The form sense base has twenty kinds, namely long, short, square, round, beautiful, ugly, high, low, blue, yellow, red, white, light, shadow, brightness, darkness, clouds, smoke, dust, and mist.
There are also those who say there are twenty-one kinds, with twenty kinds as explained above, and one kind of space as form.
Among these twenty kinds of form, how many have form but no shape, and how many have form and shape?
Answer:
Eight have form but no shape, namely blue, yellow, red, white, light, shadow, brightness, and darkness. The remaining twelve kinds have form and shape.
There are also those who make four statements, either having form but no shape, or having shape but no form, and so on, making four statements in detail.
Having form but no shape refers to the eight kinds of blue, yellow, red, white, light, shadow, brightness, and darkness.
Having shape but no form refers to the form of bodily action.
Having form and shape refers to the twelve kinds of long, short, square, round, good, bad, high, low, clouds, mist, dust, and fog.
Having neither form nor shape refers to form that has no form and also no shape.
Question:
What is the meaning of visible?
What is the meaning of invisible?
The Venerable Vasumitra said:
Because it can be seen here and there, this is the meaning of visible.
Because it cannot be seen here and there, this is the meaning of invisible.
Venerable BuddhatrÄta says:
This is the domain of the eye, this is where the eye functions, this is the meaning of visible.
Opposed to this, this is the meaning of invisible.
Question:
Are the reflections in a water vessel and in a mirror real or unreal?
The proponents of similes say they are unreal.
Why is it so?
The mirror does not enter the face, and the face does not enter the mirror, so how can they be real?
The Abhidharma masters say they are real.
Why is it so?
Because this form sense base is the object of eye consciousness.
Question:
The face does not enter the mirror, and the mirror does not enter the face, so how can they be real?
Answer:
It is said that various kinds of produced form are the form sense base, not a single kind of produced form.

Just as water comes out by relying on the moon, moonlight pearls, and vessels, and fire comes out by relying on the sun, sunlight pearls, and dry cow dung, and has the function of fire, it is not without reality.
Just as fire comes out by relying on fire sticks, fire drills, and human effort, and has the function of fire, it is not without reality.
In the same way, by relying on a mirror and a face, a reflection arises in the mirror, and the reflection actually has the function of producing eye consciousness, it is not without reality.
Is the sound that is heard an echo real or unreal?
The proponents of similes say it is unreal.
Why is that?
Because when a sound arises in a single moment, that sound ceases in that very moment, how could it have time to produce an echo?
The proponents of Abhidharma say it is real.
Why is that?
Because it is an object of the ears, and is cognized by ear-consciousness.
The question is asked:
Just as when a sound arises in a single instant, that sound ceases in that very instant. How could there be time to produce an echo?
Answer:
It is said that various kinds of sounds that arise are the sound sense base, not just one kind of sound that arises.
Just as when the tongue, teeth, lips, nose, throat, and other parts come into contact, a sound arises that can produce ear consciousness, it is not without reality.
It is the same for that [echo].
There are two dharmas:
Obstructing dharmas and non-obstructing dharmas.
Question:
Why did you compose this treatise?
Answer:
In order to stop people's views and show that wisdom is rare, as explained above in detail.
What are obstructing dharmas?
Answer:
The ten sense bases of form, namely the five internal sense bases and the five external sense bases.
What are non-obstructing dharmas?
Answer:
The two sense bases, namely the mind sense base and the dharma sense base.
There are three kinds of obstruction:
1. Obstruction by hindrance;
2. Obstruction by object;
Third, conditioned opposition.
Obstructive opposition refers to when one hand strikes another hand, mutually obstructing each other;
when one stone strikes another stone, mutually obstructing each other. Such are called obstructive oppositions.
Objective opposition refers to the eye facing form, etc., which is called objective opposition.
Conditioned opposition refers to the mind and mental factors each taking their own objects, which is called conditioned opposition.
Among these three kinds of opposition, this treatise is based on obstructive opposition.
Question:
How many sense bases are obstructed?
Answer:
Some say that one sense base is obstructed, namely the sense base of touch, while the other sense bases are not touched.

Others say that five sense bases are obstructed, within the internal sense bases, the body sense base is obstructed; within the external sense bases, the sense bases of form, smell, taste, and touch are obstructed.
If it is said that five sense bases are obstructed, when one hand strikes another hand, five strike five;
When the hand strikes a stone, the five strike the four;
when a stone strikes a stone, the four strike the four;
when a stone strikes the hand, the four strike the five.
Again, some say: The obstruction of formless entry, excluding the sound entry.
When the hand strikes the eye, isn't it obstructed?
The discussion says:
It should be said:
The obstruction of ten entries.
If the sound entry is not obstructed, then sound has no meaning of accumulation.
The SÅ«tra on the Presentation of Phenomena says:
The eye definitely faces form, form definitely faces the eye, up to the mind definitely faces phenomena, phenomena definitely face the mind.
That Venerable One's treatise says the object has resistance. There are eyes that are unobstructed in water but obstructed on land, like those of fish, etc.
There are eyes that are unobstructed on land but obstructed in water, like those of humans, etc.
They are not obstructed in water and not obstructed on land, like the person called Balaka and the water-born Rakshasa.
Those who are obstructed in water and obstructed on land are excluded from the above.
There are eyes that are not obstructed at night but are obstructed during the day, like owls and so on.
Those that are not obstructed during the day but are obstructed at night are like humans and so on.
Those that are not obstructed during the day or night are like deer, horses, foxes, cats, and so on.
Those that are obstructed during the day and night are excluded from the above.
Among these, which are resistant?
Which are non-resistant?
The answer is:
If the subtle dust particles are accumulated, they are resistant. If the subtle dust particles are not accumulated, they are non-resistant.
Furthermore, those with various different characteristics are resistant. Those without various different characteristics are non-resistant.
Furthermore, those with an obscured appearance are resistant. Those with an unobstructed appearance are non-resistant.
Furthermore, if the characteristic of aggregation is resistance, the characteristic of non-aggregation is non-resistance.
Furthermore, if there is a large form and mass, it is resistance; if there is no large form and mass, it is non-resistance.
Furthermore, if it can be removed, it is resistance; if it cannot be removed, it is non-resistance.
The Venerable Vasumitra said:

If there is a characteristic of difference, then there is obstruction; if there is obstruction, then there is aggregation; if there is aggregation, then there is form and mass; then it can be removed; if it can be removed, then it is resistance;
the opposite of this is non-resistance.
The Venerable Harivarman said:
There is a characteristic of difference and a characteristic of obstruction, which is resistance;
there is no characteristic of difference and no characteristic of obstruction, which is non-resistance.
The Venerable Buddhadeva said:
The characteristic of being removable is resistance, the characteristic of being unremovable is non-resistance.
The Venerable Ghoá¹£a said:
If it is the nature of accumulated subtle dust, has form that can be designated as long or short, and can also produce sound, then it is resistant.
The nature of accumulated subtle dust is said to be the eight sense bases.
That which has form that can be designated as long or short is said to be the sense base of form.
That which can also produce sound is said to be the sense base of sound.
The opposite of the above is non-resistant.
The Venerable Vamula said:
The accumulation of many subtle dust particles is resistant, and the opposite of this is non-resistant.
There are two dharmas:
defiled dharmas and undefiled dharmas.
Question:
Why was this treatise composed?
Answer:
In order to stop people's views and show the rarity of wisdom, as explained above in detail.
Furthermore, some say that the reason for composing this treatise is to stop the intention of those who hold a comprehensive view.
Like the MahÄsÄá¹ƒghika school says:

Question:
Why did they make this statement?
Answer:
They rely on the Buddha's sutras.
The Buddha's sutras say:
The TathÄgata is born in the world and grows up in the world, but he transcends the world and is not defiled by the world.
They say:
If the Buddha transcends the world and is not defiled by the world, then we know that the Buddha's body is entirely undefiled.
To stop those who say this, and also to clarify that the Buddha's body is defiled,
if the Buddha's body were undefiled, then the woman named AnupamÄ would not have given rise to a mind of love for the Buddha's body.
The rest is explained in detail in the Ká¹£udraka-Ägama.
What are defiled dharmas?
Answer:
The ten sense bases and a part of two sense bases, namely the sense base of mind and the sense base of dharmas.
What are undefiled dharmas?
Answer:
A part of two sense bases, namely the sense base of mind and the sense base of dharmas.
Question:
Why are they called defiled dharmas and undefiled dharmas?
Answer:
If a dharma can increase existence, it is defiled. Opposed to this, it is undefiled.
Furthermore, if a dharma can cause continuity and increase birth, old age, sickness, and death, it is contaminated. The opposite of this is uncontaminated.
Explained in detail.
If a dharma falls into the truth of suffering and the truth of accumulation, it is contaminated. The opposite of this is uncontaminated.
The Venerable Vasumitra said:ğŸ”½What are the characteristics of contamination?
What are the characteristics of non-contamination?
The answer is:
That which arises from contamination is characterized by contamination;
That which does not arise from contamination is characterized by non-contamination.
Furthermore, that which can give rise to contamination is contamination;
That which cannot give rise to contamination is non-contamination.
The Venerable Buddhadeva said:
That which can give rise to contamination is characterized by contamination;
That which cannot give rise to contamination is characterized by non-contamination.
Two dharmas:
Conditioned dharmas and unconditioned dharmas.
Question:
Why is this treatise composed?
Answer:
To stop people's views and to show the rarity of wisdom, it is explained in detail as above.
What are conditioned dharmas?
Answer:
Eleven sense bases, and a small part of one sense base, namely the dharma sense base.
What are unconditioned dharmas?
Answer:
A small part of one sense base, namely the dharma sense base.
Question:
Why are they called conditioned and unconditioned dharmas?
Answer:
If a dharma has arising and ceasing, has causes, and has conditioned characteristics, it is a conditioned dharma;
Opposed to this, it is an unconditioned dharma.
Furthermore, if a dharma belongs to causes, belongs to conditions, belongs to what is made, belongs to combination, it is a conditioned dharma;
Opposed to this, it is an unconditioned dharma.
Furthermore, if a dharma is produced by arising, abides by abiding, and ages by aging, it is a conditioned dharma;
Opposed to this, it is an unconditioned dharma.
Furthermore, if a dharma operates in the world, can accumulate results, can cognize conditions, and can be produced, it is a conditioned dharma;
The opposite of this is an unconditioned dharma.
Furthermore, if a dharma falls into the world, belongs to the aggregates, is a continuum of suffering, has a before and after, and has a high, middle, and low, it is a conditioned dharma;
The opposite of this is an unconditioned dharma.
Venerable Vasumitra said:
What are the characteristics of the conditioned?
Answer:
The characteristics of the world and the characteristics of the aggregates are the characteristics of the conditioned.
What are the characteristics of the unconditioned?
Answer:
The non-characteristics of the world and the non-characteristics of the aggregates are the characteristics of the unconditioned.
Venerable Buddhadeva said:
If there is arising and ceasing due to sentient beings, it is a characteristic of the conditioned;
If there is no arising and ceasing not due to sentient beings, it is a characteristic of the unconditioned.
There are three dharmas:
Past dharmas, future dharmas, and present dharmas.
What are past dharmas?
Answer:
The five aggregates of the past.
What are future dharmas?
Answer:
The five aggregates of the future.
What are present dharmas?
Answer:
The five aggregates of the present.
Question:
Why was this treatise composed?
Answer:
In order to stop the intention of those who hold the doctrine of annihilation.
Just as the proponents of similes say:
The world is permanent, while the activities are impermanent.
When activities move through the world, it is like an object moving from one container to another, just as many people move from one house to another.
The activities moving through the world are also like this.
In order to stop such statements, and to clarify that activities are the world and the world is activities, the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra states:
What is meant by the term world?
Answer:
It refers to activities.

There is another explanation: The reason for composing the treatise is to stop the view that there is no past and future, and to clarify the meaning of those who say that the present is an unconditioned dharma.
It also clarifies that past and future are real and existent characteristics. If there were no past and future, then there would be no possession or non-possession.
Like a second head, a third hand, or the thirteenth sense base, there is no possession or non-possession.
If there were no past and future, then there would be no possession or non-possession.
If there is possession or non-possession, then one should know that there must be past and future, which are real and existent characteristics.
If one says there is no past and future, then one should say:
If one creates causes in the present, should the result be said to be in the past, future, or present?
If it is in the past, one should say there is a past, and should not say there is no past;
If you say it does not exist in the past, this is not so.
If you say it exists in the future, you should say there is a future, not that there is no future;
if you say there is no future, this is not so.
If you say it exists in the present, then cause and effect would coexist.
If cause and effect coexist, then it contradicts the verse.
As it is said:
Doing evil is not immediately experienced, unlike milk turning into curd;
Fools step on ashes and fire, not immediately burning their feet.

If the effect does not exist in the past, future, or present, then there is no effect. If there is no effect, then there is no cause, like a second head, a third hand, a sixth cover, or a thirteenth sense base.
If there is a cause and effect that does not exist in the past, future, or present, then it is permanent, like unconditioned dharmas.
If the effect exists in the present, then the cause should be said to exist in what place?
Is it in the past, future, or present?
If it is in the past, it is also as explained above;
if it is in the future, it is also as explained above;
if it is in the present, it is also as explained above.
If it is not in the past, future, or present, then there is no cause. If there is no cause, then there is no effect, like a second head, a third hand, a sixth aggregate, or a thirteenth sense base.
If there is a cause and effect that is not in the three times, then it should be permanent, like unconditioned dharmas.
Furthermore, if there is no past or future, then there is no Dharma of going forth.
As a verse says:
If one says there is no past, then there are no past buddhas.
If there are no past buddhas, then there is no Dharma of going forth.
Furthermore, if there is no past or future, then one always speaks falsely.
As a verse says:
If one says there is no past, yet speaks of years,
Then it is always false speech at all times.
Moreover, if there is no past or future, then there is no present.
Why is it so?
Because there is a past and future, the present is established.
If there are no three times, there are no conditioned dharmas. If there are no conditioned dharmas, there are also no unconditioned dharmas.
Why is it so?
Because there are conditioned dharmas, the unconditioned is established.
If there are no conditioned or unconditioned dharmas, then there are no all dharmas.
If there are no all dharmas, then there is no liberation and emancipation.
In order to avoid such faults, it is said that the past and future are truly existent characteristics.

Therefore, in order to stop the meaning of others and reveal one's own meaning, and also to reveal the meaning of the characteristics of dharmas that are in accordance with reality, this treatise is composed.
Question:
What is the essence of the world?
Answer:
The five aggregates of the past, future, and present - this is the essence of the world, and so on, explained in detail.
The reason for the essence has already been explained, now we will explain why it is called the world.
What is the meaning of the world?
The answer is:
The meaning of going is the meaning of the world.
The question is:
If the formations do not come and go, then if they come they do not go, and if they go they do not come.
If they come, then the place of coming should be empty.
Why is it so?
Because they come from that place.
If they go, then going is obstructed.
Why is it so?
Because going reaches that place.
Therefore, the Venerable Vasumitra spoke this verse:
The formations have no characteristic of coming, because of the moments,
And have no characteristic of going, and also no one who abides.
If the formations have no coming and going, how can there be the three times?
The answer is:
Because of what is done.
If the activities of all dharmas are not yet performed, this is called the future;
If they are performed, this is called the present;
If the performance has already ceased, this is called the past.
If the eye has not yet seen form, this is seeing form in the future, this is seeing form in the present, and this is seeing form in the past that has already ceased.
Question:
If so, how can the present part of the eye perform activities?
Answer:
Because it acts as a similar cause.
If it is not present, it does not act as a similar cause for the future;
If it is present, it acts as a similar cause for the future.
Up to the mind, it is also like this.ğŸ”½Like form that has not yet obstructed is the future, if it obstructs is the present, if obstruction has already ceased is the past.
Like feeling that has not yet arisen is the future, if feeling arises is the present, if feeling has arisen and ceased is the past.

Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are also like this.ğŸ”½Furthermore, if a dharma has not yet taken its fruit and is giving its fruit, it is future; if it has taken its fruit and is giving its fruit, it is present; if it has taken its fruit and given its fruit and has ceased, it is past.

Furthermore, if a dharma has not yet taken its dominant fruit and retribution fruit, it is future; if it has taken its dominant fruit and retribution fruit but has not yet given them, it is present; if it has taken its dominant fruit and retribution fruit and has ceased, it is past.
Furthermore, if a dharma has not yet given its similar cause and universal cause, it is future; if it has given them, it is present; if it has given them and has ceased, it is past.
Furthermore, if a dharma has not yet arisen and has not yet ceased, it is future; if it has already arisen but has not yet ceased, it is present; if it has arisen and has ceased, it is past.

Not yet arisen and not yet destroyed, already arisen and not yet destroyed, already arisen and already destroyed; not yet arisen and not yet separated, already arisen and not yet separated, already arisen and already separated, the explanation is also like this.

Furthermore, if a dharma has not yet produced the three characteristics of conditioned [dharmas], it is future. If it has already produced one and is now producing two, it is present. If it has already produced three, it is past.

Furthermore, if a dharma has not yet produced the four conditions, it is future. If it produces the four conditions, it is present. If it has already produced the four conditions and has ceased, it is past.
Furthermore, if a dharma acts as a cause for the three times, it is past. If it acts as a cause for two times, it is present. If it acts as a cause for one time, it is future.

Furthermore, if a dharma is the effect of the three times, it is future. If it is the effect of two times, it is present. If it is the effect of one time, it is past.ğŸ”½Furthermore, the present is established based on the past and future, but the present is not established based on the present, because there is no fourth time.
The future is established based on the past and present, but the future is not established based on the future, because there is no fourth time.
The future and present are established based on the past, but the past is not established based on the past, because there is no fourth time period.
Are all that exist in the past the same as that which exists in form?
Answer:ğŸ”½There are four possibilities.ğŸ”½That which exists in the past but not in form: the four aggregates in the past.
That which exists in form but not in the past: that which exists in form in the future and present.
That which exists in the past and also in form: that which exists in form in the past.
That which does not exist in the past nor in form: that which exists in the four aggregates and the unconditioned in the future and present.
Just as there are four possibilities for form, there are also four possibilities for consciousness.
Just as there are five sets of four possibilities for the past, there are also five sets of four possibilities for the future and present, making fifteen sets of four possibilities in total.
If that which exists in form is all that which exists in the limited,
Answer:
If it is a part of a direction, it is all a part of form.
Is there any part of form that is not a part of a direction?
Answer:
There is.
Past and future form, present atoms, and unconditioned form.
If it is a part of feeling, is it all not a part of a direction?
Answer:
If it is a part of feeling, it is all not a part of a direction.
Is there anything that is not a part of a direction but not a part of feeling?
Answer:
There is.
The parts of perception, conception, and consciousness, past and future form, present atoms, unconditioned form, and the parts of unconditioned phenomena.
The explanation of perception, conception, and consciousness is also like this.
Are all existing forms obstructive?
Answer:
If they are obstructive, they are all parts of form.
Is there any form that is not obstructive?
Answer:
There is.
past and future form, present subtle particles, and unconditioned form.
Are all feelings exhaustively perceived?
Answer:
If perceived, they are all feelings.
Are there any feelings that are not perceived?
Answer:
There are.
Past and future feelings.
The explanation of perception, conception, and consciousness is also like this.
Question:
Is it the born that is born, or the unborn that is born?
If it is the born that is born, why are conditioned phenomena not reversible?
If it is the unborn that is born, why are conditioned phenomena not originally non-existent and then existent?
Answer:
It should be said:
Because of events, the born is born, and because of events, the unborn is born.
As for the born being born because of events, it is because dharmas originally abide in their own nature and characteristics that they are born.
As for the unborn being born because of events, it is because all future dharmas are unborn dharmas that they are born.
Question:
Is it the world that is born, or is it born within the world?
If the world arises, why don't all dharmas arise when one dharma arises?
If all dharmas arise when one dharma arises, then the world is destroyed.
If it arises in the world, why is it not different from the world?
Answer:
It should be said:
The world arises because of events, and the world arises in the world because of events.
As for the world arising because of events, when one moment arises, it is the world.
As for the world arising in the world because of events, in the future world, one moment arises while the other moments have not yet arisen.
Question:
Do the dharmas that arise cease due to those dharmas, or do the dharmas that arise cease due to other dharmas?
If the dharmas that arise cease due to those dharmas, do the future dharmas that arise cease due to future dharmas?
If the dharmas that arise cease due to other dharmas, do form arise and feeling cease?ğŸ”½Answer:
It should be said:
Because of this, the arising of a dharma is precisely the cessation of that dharma, and because of this, the arising of another dharma is precisely the cessation of another dharma.

As for because of this, the arising of a dharma is precisely the cessation of that dharma, the arising of form is precisely the cessation of form, up to the arising of consciousness is precisely the cessation of consciousness.
As for because of this, the arising of another dharma is precisely the cessation of another dharma, what arises in the future is what ceases in the present.
Question:
Does it arise from its own part or from another's part?
If it arises from its own part, how is it that what originally had no own part comes to have an own part, and what originally had no substance comes to have substance?
If it arises from another's part, how is it that a dharma does not abandon its own nature?
Answer:
It should be said:
It does not arise from its own part nor from another's part, but rather, having arisen according to the nature of the dharma, it ceases.
Question:
Since the future diminishes and the past increases, why is it not established that the two times have increase and decrease?
The Venerable Vasumitra said:
Do past and future worlds increase and decrease in number?
If past and future worlds do not increase in number, why is it said that past and future worlds have increase and decrease?
Moreover, past and future are immeasurable and boundless, and it is not said that they have increase and decrease.

It is like taking a hundred thousand jars of water from the ocean, which does not decrease, or pouring a hundred thousand jars of water into it, which does not increase, because the water in the ocean is immeasurable.
It is the same with that.

Moreover, future dharmas have not yet arisen and have not yet ceased, so they do not decrease; past dharmas have already arisen and have already ceased, so they do not increase.ğŸ”½Moreover, future dharmas have not yet arisen and are not yet destroyed, so they do not decrease; past dharmas have already arisen and have already been destroyed, so they do not increase.
Moreover, future dharmas have not yet arisen and are not yet separated, so they do not decrease; past dharmas have already arisen and have already been separated, so they do not increase.
The Venerable Buddhadeva said:
If a dharma moves through time, why is it not said to have increase and decrease?
It is just that dharmas arise due to the combination of causes and conditions, and cease when the causes and conditions disperse.

Or are they scattered in various places?
If they are accumulated, how can the offerings made by donors not be wasted?

Answer:
It should be said:

Question:

Answer:
Because others can see it.
If they do not cultivate merit, it does not appear, but if they cultivate merit, it appears.
Question:

Answer:
If it has a specific location, what further fault is there?
How is it not permanent?
Answer:
Because it is momentary and impermanent.

Answer:
If it has not yet become the object of the five sense consciousnesses, it does not appear, but if it has become so, it appears.
The judges say:
It should be said:
The present is accumulation, and the future and past are scattered everywhere.
Why is this?
Because it is included in the dharmas.
Question:
If so, how can it be said to exist in the past?
Answer:
It is said to be past as it was originally in the present.
How can it be said to exist in the future?
Answer:
As it will be in the present in the future.
How is the past the object of knowledge of past lives and knowledge through resolve?
Answer:
Because it is as it was experienced.
It is like a previously experienced word, sequentially forming a sentence to express the meaning.
In the same way, they sequentially recollect past experiences, giving rise to knowledge and insight.
How is the future the object of knowledge through resolve?
Answer:
It is known by analogy with the past and present.
It is like a farmer knowing by analogy.
How is it not that which did not exist before but exists now, or that which existed returns to nonexistence?
Answer:
This cannot be explained.
There are four kinds of logicians in the SarvÄstivÄda:ğŸ”½1. Those who say the substance is different;
2. Those who say the characteristics are different;
Third, the difference in time of speaking;
Fourth, the difference in speaking.
As for the difference in events, it is said:
When dharmas function in the world, the events are different but the substance is not different.
It is like gold and silver vessels, which are broken and remade. Although the shapes are different, their colors are not different.
It is also like milk turning into curd. Although the fragrance and taste are different, the color is not different.
In this way, when future dharmas reach the present, although they abandon future dharmas, they do not abandon their substance;
When present dharmas reach the past, although they abandon present dharmas, they do not abandon their substance.
As for the difference in characteristics, it is said:
When dharmas function in the world, past dharmas have the characteristic of the past, but they are not without the characteristics of the future and present;
Future dharmas have the characteristic of the future, but they are not without the characteristics of the past and present;
Present dharmas have the characteristic of the present, but they are not without the characteristics of the past and future.
It is like a person who loves the color of one woman, but it is not that he does not love the colors of other women.
It is the same with this.
Those who say that time is different say:
When dharmas are in the world, because of the difference in time, different names arise, but not because of a difference in their substance.
It is like counting sticks. The first stick is called one, one turn is called ten, and another turn is called a hundred, and so on up to ten thousand.
The counting stick is one, but because of its different positions, it has various names.
It is the same with this.
Those who say this about time are called non-harassing speakers, because of what is done, there are the three times.
If a dharma has not yet been done, it is called future, if it has been done, it is called present, and if the doing has already ceased, it is called past.
Those who say that difference is different say:
When dharmas are in the world, because of what comes before and after, different names arise.
It is like a single woman who is called a daughter and also called a mother. Because she has a mother, she is called a daughter, and because she has a daughter, she is called a mother.
When such dharmas function in the world, the past and future are different, not the present. The substance is different.
One who speaks like this is called a troublemaker.
Why is it so?
One world has the three times.
The past world has the three times. The two moments before and after the past are called past and future, and the moment in the past is called past.
The present and future worlds are also like this.
Question:

Three dharmas:
Wholesome dharmas, unwholesome dharmas, and indeterminate dharmas.
What are wholesome dharmas?
Answer:
The five wholesome aggregates and cessation through deliberation.
What are unwholesome dharmas?
Answer:
The five unwholesome aggregates.
What are indeterminate dharmas?
Answer:
The indeterminate five aggregates, space, and non-analytical cessation.
Why are they called wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate?
The detailed explanation is as in the chapter on unwholesome [phenomena].
There are three kinds of phenomena:
Phenomena associated with the desire realm, phenomena associated with the form realm, and phenomena associated with the formless realm.
What are phenomena associated with the desire realm?
Answer:
The five aggregates associated with the desire realm.
What are phenomena associated with the form realm?
Answer:
The five aggregates associated with the form realm.
What are phenomena associated with the formless realm?
Answer:
The four aggregates associated with the formless realm.
Why are they called phenomena associated with the desire realm, form realm, and formless realm?
The detailed explanation is as above.
There are three kinds of phenomena:
Phenomena of learners, phenomena of post-learners, and phenomena of neither learners nor post-learners.
What are phenomena of learners?
Answer:
The five aggregates of learners.
What are phenomena of post-learners?
Answer:
The five aggregates of post-learners.
What are phenomena of neither learners nor post-learners?
Answer:
The five contaminated aggregates and the unconditioned.
Why are they called learners, post-learners, and neither learners nor post-learners?
Answer:

Because they learn to eliminate greed through the path of non-greed, they are called learners. Because they do not learn to eliminate greed through the path of non-greed, they are called post-learners.
Why is it so?
Because they have already learned.
The opposite of this is called neither learner nor post-learner.
The explanations for non-hatred and non-delusion are the same.ğŸ”½Furthermore, because they learn to eliminate craving through the path of non-craving, that non-craving nature is learning.
Because they learn to eliminate craving through the path of non-craving, it excludes the post-learner's path;
The non-craving nature excludes the mundane path.
Because they do not learn to eliminate craving through the path of non-craving, because they have already learned,
The non-craving nature is post-learning.
Because they do not learn to eliminate craving through the path of non-craving, it excludes the path nature; The non-craving nature excludes the mundane path.
The opposite of this is neither learner nor post-learner.
Furthermore, one who studies to eliminate afflictions and studies to see the truth is a learner, while one who does not study to eliminate afflictions has already eliminated them before.
One who sees the truth has already seen it before, so he is a post-learner.
The opposite of this is neither a learner nor a post-learner.
Furthermore, a learner eliminates two kinds of seeking, namely the seeking of desire and the seeking of existence.
A learner eliminates two kinds of seeking and fulfills one kind of seeking, namely the seeking of the holy life, so he is a learner.
One who does not study to eliminate two kinds of seeking has already eliminated them before, so he does not study;
he fulfills one kind of seeking, which he has already fulfilled before, so he is a post-learner.
The opposite of this is neither a learner nor a post-learner.
Furthermore, if in one's body there is the attainment of afflictions and also the attainment of undefiled dharmas, eliminating afflictions through study is a learner;
if in one's body there is no attainment of afflictions and there is the attainment of undefiled dharmas, not studying to eliminate afflictions is a post-learner.
The opposite of this is neither a learner nor a post-learner.
Furthermore, one cannot attain the uncontaminated dharmas without being free from craving.
Cutting off craving while still learning is learning.
Being free from craving and attaining the uncontaminated dharmas without further learning is no learning.
The opposite of this is neither learning nor no learning.
Furthermore, that which is included in the path of insight and the path of cultivation is learning, and that which is included in the path of no learning is no learning.
The same explanation applies to the three stages and the three faculties.
Furthermore, if the uncontaminated dharmas can be attained in the body of the five kinds of people, it is learning.
The five kinds of people refer to those of firm faith, firm Dharma, liberation through faith, insight into the truth, and bodily realization.
If the uncontaminated dharmas can be attained in the body of the two kinds of people, it is no learning.
The two kinds of people refer to those liberated at times and those liberated at all times.
The opposite of this is neither learning nor no learning.
Furthermore, if the uncontaminated dharmas can be attained in the body of the seven kinds of people, it is learning.
The seven people refer to those in the four stages of entering the stream and abiding in the three fruits.
If the uncontaminated dharmas can be obtained in the body of one person, they are of the adept.
The one person refers to those abiding in one fruit.
The opposite of this is neither training nor post-training.

Furthermore, if the uncontaminated dharmas can be obtained in the bodies of eighteen people, they are of the training. If the uncontaminated dharmas can be obtained in the bodies of adepts, they are of the adept. The opposite of this is neither training nor post-training.
There are three dharmas:
Dharmas to be eliminated by the path of insight, dharmas to be eliminated by the path of cultivation, and dharmas not to be eliminated.
What are the dharmas to be eliminated by the path of insight?
Answer:
If a dharma is eliminated by the perseverance of insight and the perseverance of the practice of insight,
What are they?
Answer:

The eighty-eight bonds to be eliminated by the path of insight, as well as the associated dharmas and the co-arisen dharmas that arise from them, are called the dharmas to be eliminated by the path of insight.
What are the dharmas to be eliminated by the path of cultivation?
Answer:
If a dharma is to be eliminated by the path of cultivation by one who is a learner and has attained the state of no regression through the path of insight,
what is that?
Answer:

The ten defilements to be eliminated by the path of cultivation, as well as the dharmas associated with them, the bodily and verbal actions produced by them, the co-arisen dharmas, and the defiled and impure dharmas, are called the dharmas to be eliminated by the path of cultivation.
What are the dharmas that are not to be eliminated?
Answer:
The pure dharmas.
Question:
Why are they called dharmas to be eliminated by the path of insight, by the path of cultivation, and dharmas that are not to be eliminated?
Answer:
The detailed explanation is as above.
Four truths:
The truth of suffering, the truth of the accumulation of suffering, the truth of the cessation of suffering, and the truth of the path.

Question:
What is the essential nature of the truths?
The answer is:
The Abhidharma masters say:

The five appropriated aggregates are the truth of suffering, contaminated causes are the truth of origination, cessation through analysis is the truth of cessation, and the factors of the path of training and no-more-training are the truth of the path.
The proponents of similes say:

Name-and-form is the truth of suffering, afflictions and karma are the truth of origination, the exhaustion of afflictions and karma is the truth of cessation, and concentration and wisdom are the truth of the path.
VibhajyavÄdins say:
The eight aspects of suffering are suffering and the truth of suffering, other contaminated dharmas are suffering but not the truth of suffering;
craving that produces subsequent existence is origination and the truth of origination, other cravings and other contaminated dharmas are origination but not the truth of origination;

the exhaustion of craving that produces subsequent existence is cessation and the truth of cessation, the exhaustion of other cravings and other contaminated dharmas is cessation but not the truth of cessation;
the eight factors of the path of training are the path and the truth of the path, other factors of the path of training and all factors of no-more-training are the path but not the truth of the path.
If it is as you say, then the arhat would accomplish two truths, namely the truth of suffering and the truth of cessation, and would not accomplish the truth of accumulation.
Why is this?
The craving for future existence is the truth of accumulation. The arhat has already severed the craving for future existence.
He would not accomplish the truth of the path. Why is this?
They say that the eightfold noble path of the learner is the truth of the path. The arhat has already abandoned it upon attaining the fruit.
The Venerable Ghoá¹£a says:

Whether it is the aggregates of one's own body, the aggregates of another's body, or the aggregates of sentient beings or non-sentient beings, all of this is suffering, which is the truth of suffering.
When the practitioner sees suffering, he sees his own body's suffering, not the suffering of another's body or that which is not a sentient being.
Why is this?
The meaning of oppression is the meaning of suffering. The suffering of another's body and that which is not a sentient being does not oppress, therefore.
For this reason, the JÄti-jÃ±Äna-kathÄ says like this:
The suffering that afflicts one's own body is not the suffering of others' bodies, nor is it not caused by one's own body and then afflicting others.
If there were no one's own body, what suffering of others' bodies and non-sentient beings would be afflicted?
If the cause of suffering in one's own body and the cause of suffering in others' bodies and sentient beings are accumulation, then they are the truth of accumulation.

When practitioners see accumulation, they see the cause of suffering in their own body, but they do not see the cause of suffering in others' bodies, nor do they see the cause of suffering in non-sentient beings.

If the cessation of suffering in one's own body, the cessation of suffering in others' bodies, and the cessation of suffering in sentient beings and non-sentient beings are cessation, then they are the truth of cessation.
When practitioners see cessation, they see the cessation in their own body, but not the cessation in others' bodies, nor the cessation in non-sentient beings.
If the antidote in one's own body, the antidote in others' bodies, and the antidote in sentient beings and non-sentient beings are the path, then they are the truth of the path.
When practitioners see the path, they see the counteractive path of their own body, not the counteractive path of others' bodies or non-sentient things.
The Abhidharma masters say:
Whether it is the suffering of one's own body, the suffering of others' bodies, or the suffering of sentient and non-sentient things, when practitioners see suffering, they see all such suffering.
Question:
When practitioners see suffering, they see oppressive suffering.
The suffering in others' bodies and the suffering of non-sentient things are not oppressive. Why do practitioners see them when they see suffering?
Answer:
Although that suffering is not oppressive, it is the object of delusion, and wisdom should arise from it;
it is the object of doubt, and determination should arise from it;
it is the object of slander, and faith and respect should arise from it.
Who says:
The suffering in others' bodies and the suffering of non-sentient things are not oppressive?
If one is beaten by others, is that not oppressive?
If a piece of wood or stone falls on one's body in space, is it not a painful affliction?

If the causes of one's own aggregates, the causes of others' aggregates, or the causes of the aggregates of sentient beings and non-sentient beings are all accumulation, they are the truth of accumulation. When a practitioner sees accumulation, they see all of it.

If the cessation of one's own suffering, the cessation of others' suffering, or the cessation of the suffering of sentient beings and non-sentient beings is cessation, it is the truth of cessation. When a practitioner sees cessation, they see all of it.

If the antidotes to one's own aggregates, the antidotes to others' aggregates, or the antidotes to the aggregates of sentient beings and non-sentient beings are all the path, they are the truth of the path. When a practitioner sees the path, they see all of it.
This is the essence of the truths, and so on in detail.
The reason for the essence has already been explained. Now, why are they called truths?
What is the meaning of truth?
The answer is:
The meaning of reality is the meaning of truth, the meaning of certainty, the meaning of suchness, the meaning of non-erroneousness, and the meaning of non-difference are the meaning of truth.
Question:

If the meaning of reality, the meaning of truth, the meaning of suchness, the meaning of non-erroneousness, and the meaning of non-difference are the meaning of truth, then space and non-analytical cessation are also the meaning of reality up to the meaning of non-difference. Why are they not established as truths?
Answer:
If a dharma is suffering, the cause of suffering, the cessation of suffering, or the antidote to suffering, it is established as a truth;
Space and non-analytical cessation are neither suffering, nor the cause of suffering, nor the cessation of suffering, nor the antidote to suffering, so they are not established as truths.
As with suffering, the aggregates, illness, boils, arrows, afflictions, and heavy burdens are explained in the same way.
Furthermore, if a dharma is like this shore, the other shore, or a raft on a river, it is established as a truth;
Space and non-analytical cessation are neither this shore, the other shore, nor a raft on a river, so they are not established as truths.
Furthermore, if a dharma is suffering, the cause of suffering, the path, or the fruit of the path, it is established as a truth;
Space and non-analytical cessation are contrary to the above, so they are not established as truths.
Furthermore, if a dharma has causes and effects, it is established as a truth.
Space and non-analytical cessation have no causes or effects, so they are not established as truths.

Furthermore, space and non-analytical cessation are uncontaminated, so they are not truths of suffering or accumulation. They are indeterminate, so they are not truths of cessation. They are unconditioned, so they are not truths of the path.
Furthermore, these dharmas do not function in the world, so they are not established as three truths. They are indeterminate, so they are not established as truths of cessation.
Furthermore, these dharmas are not aggregates, so they are not established as three truths. They are not wholesome, so they are not established as truths of cessation.

Furthermore, these dharmas do not accompany suffering, so they are not established as three truths. They are not wholesome, so they are not established as truths of cessation.ğŸ”½Furthermore, if a dharma is established as a truth because it is the object of wrong views and uncontaminated right views, this dharma is not the object of wrong views and uncontaminated right views, so it is not established as a truth.

Furthermore, if a dharma is established as a truth because it is the object of ignorance and the light of wisdom, this dharma is not the object of ignorance and the light of wisdom, so it is not established as a truth.
Furthermore, if a dharma is an affliction or a means of liberation, it is established as a truth. This dharma is neither an affliction nor a means of liberation, so it is not established as a truth.
Furthermore, if a dharma can give rise to disgust and joy, it is established as a truth. This dharma cannot give rise to disgust and joy, so it is not established as a truth.
Question:
If the meaning of non-delusion is the meaning of truth, then delusion should not be included in the truths.
Why is that?
Because its essence is delusion.
Answer:
Delusion is established by other things, and is included in the truths by other things.
Delusion is established by three things:
First, it is intense due to its rapid movement;
Second, it is false;
Third, it is one-sided delusion.
Because this dharma has a real essence, it is included in the truths.
Furthermore, it is delusion to take the impermanent as permanent, suffering as happiness, the impure as pure, and non-self as self.
Because this dharma has causes and effects, it is included in the truths.
Question:
If the meaning of non-differentiation is the meaning of truth, then false speech should not be included in the truths.
Why is that?
Because false speech is made with the intention to deceive others by speaking differently.
Answer:
False speech is established for another purpose, and is included in the truths for another purpose.
False speech is established because of speaking differently to deceive others, and is included in the truths because of having a real nature.

Moreover, false speech is established because of saying I see when one does not see, saying I hear when one does not hear, saying I know when one does not know, and saying I recognize when one does not recognize.
Because this dharma has causes and effects, it is included in the truths.
Therefore, the meaning of reality is the meaning of truth, and so on in detail.
Question:
How are the four truths established?
Are they established by nature, by cause and effect, or by the time of seeing?
If they are established by nature, then there are three truths.
Why is that?
Apart from suffering there is no accumulation, apart from accumulation there is no suffering. Cessation is the second truth, the path is the third truth.
If cause and effect are used, there should be five truths:
Suffering can be said to be a cause and also a result. The path can also be said to be a cause and also a result. Cessation is the fifth.
If seeing is used, there should be eight truths:
The practitioner first sees the suffering of the desire realm, and then sees the form and formless realms.
First, he sees the causes and conditions of the practices of the desire realm, and then sees the form and formless realms.
First, he sees the cessation of the practices of the desire realm, and then sees the form and formless realms.
First, he sees the path that counteracts the practices of the desire realm, and then sees the form and formless realms.
Answer:
It should be said:
The truths are established based on cause and effect.
Question:
If that is so, there should be five truths.
Answer:
Because of the general explanation, there are not five truths.
Whether cause or effect, they are collectively called suffering. Cessation and the path are collectively called the path to the end of birth, old age, sickness, and death.
Question:
If suffering, whether cause or effect, is also the path of the origin of suffering, it is also the path of birth, old age, sickness, and death.
Answer:
Because of the difference in practice.
Suffering that has the meaning of effect is practiced with four aspects, namely suffering, emptiness, impermanence, and non-self.
Suffering that has the meaning of cause is practiced with four aspects, namely cause, origin, existence, and condition.
The path also has the meaning of cause and also has the meaning of effect. It is practiced with one kind of four aspects, namely path, suchness, trace, and vehicle.
Furthermore, the four truths are established for three reasons:
First, by nature;
Second, by cause and effect;
Third, by refuting slander and giving rise to faith.
By nature, the nature of the four truths is both contaminated and uncontaminated.
By cause and effect, the nature of the contaminated is both cause and effect.
The truth of suffering is that which has results. The truth of accumulation is that which has causes.
The nature of the uncontaminated also has causes and results, and also has results without causes.
The truth of the path is that which has causes and results. The truth of cessation is that which has results without causes.
Question:
Why is the nature of the contaminated that which has results established as one truth, and that which has causes established as one truth;
and the nature of the uncontaminated that which has causes and results established as one truth?
Answer:
Because of the arising of faith through refutation.
The nature of the contaminated gives rise to two kinds of refutations, saying there is no suffering and no accumulation;
it gives rise to two kinds of faith, saying there is suffering and accumulation and the path.
If the causes and results give rise to one kind of refutation, saying there is no path;
it gives rise to one kind of faith, saying there is the path.
For these three reasons, the four truths are established.
Furthermore, the four noble truths are established because of seeing the truths at the time.
Question:
If that is so, there should be eight truths.
Answer:
Whether it is suffering in the desire realm or suffering in the form and formless realms, when seeing suffering, they are all the four aspects of suffering, etc.
Whether it is the cause of activities in the desire realm or the cause of activities in the form and formless realms, when seeing the origin, they are all the four aspects of origin, etc.
Whether it is the cessation of activities in the desire realm or the cessation of activities in the form and formless realms, when seeing cessation, they are all the four aspects of cessation, etc.
Whether it is the antidote to activities in the desire realm or the antidote to activities in the form and formless realms, when seeing the path, they are all the four aspects of the path, etc.
Therefore, because they are practiced in total when seeing the truths, there are only four truths and not eight truths.
Question:
What are the characteristics of suffering, origin, cessation, and path?
The Venerable Vasumitra said:

The characteristic of oppression is the characteristic of suffering, the characteristic of existence is the characteristic of origin, the characteristic of tranquility is the characteristic of cessation, and the characteristic of vehicle is the characteristic of the path.
The Venerable Harivarman said:

The characteristic of transformation is the characteristic of suffering, the characteristic of that which can transform is the characteristic of origin, the characteristic of cessation is the characteristic of cessation, and the characteristic of abiding and transforming is the characteristic of the path.

Furthermore, the transformation of existence is the characteristic of suffering, the ability to transform existence is the characteristic of accumulation, the exhaustion of the transformation of existence is the characteristic of cessation, and the progress towards the transformation of existence is the characteristic of the path.
The Venerable Buddhadeva said:
The substance of the four noble truths is called the five appropriated aggregates.
The substance is like a red-hot iron that has been with fire for a long time, and has the same color as the fire.
The three sufferings combined with the five appropriated aggregates are also like this, and this is the truth of suffering.
The karma that arises from afflictions and is able to transform is the truth of accumulation.
The destruction of afflictions and karma, and no longer accepting existence, is the truth of cessation.
Cultivating precepts and cultivating concentration, observing arising and ceasing with wisdom, and being able to cut off the causes of existence, is the truth of the path.
